The electrocatalytic reduction naturally abundant dinitrogen (N2) to ammonia (NH3) offers a promising alternative to the harsh Haber–Bosch process. However, developing catalysts for high-performance electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) remains a significant challenge. In this study, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed to investigate boron-transition metal atom pairs (B–TM) supported on graphitic carbon nitride (g-C6N6) as dual-atom catalysts for photo-assisted electrocatalysis of NRR. It was demonstrated that B–TM atom pair can be successfully embedded on g-C6N6. Among the considered B–TM@g-C6N6 catalysts, B–Os@g-C6N6 exhibits exceptional catalytic activity for NRR via a consecutive mechanism, with the lowest overpotential of 0.21 V, outperforming the efficiency of widely used noble catalysts. Notably, both B and Os atoms directly participate in N2 activation through σ-donation and π*-backdonation mechanism. Furthermore, the adsorption of intermediates can induce the reversable evolution of the active center, accelerating the NRR. Therefore, these novel characteristics endow B–Os dual atom catalyst with excellent NRR performance. Importantly, B–Os@g-C6N6 also shows suitable band edges and high capability of visible-light absorption, which can assist N2 conversion under visible-light irradiation. This work offers new insights and ideas for designing nonmetal-metal atom pair as dual atom catalyst for the photo-assisted electrocatalytic reduction of N2 to NH3. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dual-atom catalysts Nitrogen reduction Electrocatalysis Photocatalysis Density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Amonina (NH3), as nitrogenous compound, plays a crucial role in various fields, including medicine, agriculture, plastics and textile industries, contributing significantly to the global economy [1,2]. Currently, industrial-scale ammonia systhesis relies on the well-known Haber-Bosch process (N2+ 3H2 → 2NH3), which requires high temperature (350–550 °C) and pressure (150–250 bar), resulting in excessive energy consumption and substantial greenhouse emissions [3]. It is therefore of great importance to develop milder, low-consumption and enviromentally fridendly technologies for the ammonia production. Inspired by the natural nitrogen fixation process in bacteria, some biological catalysts have been demonstrated to be activation of N2 reduciton to NH3. Meanwhile, the identification of active center (Fe-Mo protein) of the nitrogenase enzyme encourage us to explore more catalystys with similar properties [4,5]. Recently, electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) has attracted increasing interest because it can reduce N2 to NH3 under ambident condition, making it a promising alternative method for NH3 synthesis [6–8]. Additionally, photocatalytic reactions for energy conversion also make great achievements [9–12]. Especially, photocatalytic N2 reduction has also been considered as an effective method for the NH3 production [13–15]. However, the high chemical inertness of NN triple bonds with dissociation energy of 941 kJ/mol make it diffcult to be broken. In this regard, searching catalysts for effectively activating N2 and promoting the N2 hydrogenation process is crucial for improving the NRR efficiency. To date, various catalysts such as pure metals (e.g., Au nanorods) [16], metal oxides (e.g., TiO2, ZnO) [17,18], and metal chalcogenides (e.g., MoS2, ZnS) [19,20], etc. have been employed both experimentally or theoretically for the reduction of N2 to NH3 through electrocatalytic or photocatalytic methods. Despite that noble metal catalysts exhibit great catalytic performance, their scarcity, high cost and low selectivity against hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) limit their practical application. Metal oxides generally have large band gaps, resulting in low utilization of solar energy. Metal chalcogenides, on the other hand, suffer from self-oxidation and photo-corrosion. Consequently, it is essential to explore cost-effective catalysts for N2 fixation. Over the past ten years, single atom catalysts (SACs) have achieved significant advancements in various fields. Pioneering work by Qiao et al. demonstrated 100 % utiliztion of metal atoms and high activity for CO oxidation [21]. More importantly, SACs can outperform noble metal catalysts in multiple catalytic reactions. It is worth noting that an appropriate substrate is crucial for the stability and performance of SACs, which are closely related to the coordination environment of single atom. Among numerous substrates, two dimensional (2D) materials, especially those containing nitrogen, with advantages of large surface area, porous structure and unique properties, have emerged as ideal platform for anchoring metal atoms as SACs [22–24]. In particular, SACs on graphitic carbon nitrides such as g-C3N4 and g-C2N have been studied as efficient catalysts in theoretical work [25–28]. For instance, Zhang et al. reported that single V atom anchored on g-C3N4 is beneficial to the adsorption of N2 and the inhibition of hydrogen evolution reaction, resulting in high activity and selectivity for NH3 generation [29]. Zhu et al. investigated the single transition-metal (TM) atoms supported g-C2N for the reduction of nitrates to NH3, in which W anchored g-C2N exhibit the lowest limiting potential [30]. Interestingly, single or double nonmetal atom doped graphitic carbon nitrides also exhibited excellent performance for N2 reduction to NH3. Zhu et al. demonstrated that single boron atom anchored on g-C2N showed onset potential of 0.07 V and rate-determining barrier of 0.50 eV for the reduction of N2 to NH3 based on the enzymatic mechanism [31]. They revealed that the ``acceptance-donation'' interaction between B@g-C2N and N2 is the key to activiate N2. Furthermore, Manzoor studied two born atom impregnated in g-C2N and g-C3N4 for N2 reudction [32]. Results indicated that the B2@g-C2N prefers urea generation, while B2@g-C3N4 favours ammonia formation with a limiting potential of −0.40 V due to efficient N2 activation. Obviously, these type of graphitic carbon nitrides, decorated with metal or nonmetal atoms, generally exhibit high activity for N2 fixation. Similar to g-C3N4 and g-C2N, triazine based porous g-C6N6 is also a novel catalyst, which was synthesized by reacting cyanuric chloride and sodium at 230 °C and 1.8 MPa using NiCl2 as a catalyst precursor [33]. G-C6N6 can also provide abundant coordination sites, in particular, the abundant pyridinic N sites with lone pair electrons can accommodate foreign nonmetal and metal atoms that act as active center for catalytic reactions. Besides, the conductivity and light absorption of g-C6N6 is improved due to the delocalized ᴨ-bond [34]. Therefore, g-C6N6 has also been developed for various catalytic reactions. For instance, Lv et al. investigated the photocatalytic activity of N2 reduction to NH3 over the single boron atom anchored g-C6N6, revealing that N2 can be efficiently activated and reduced to NH3 with low overpotential and activation barrier [35]. Meanwhile, the competitive HER can also be inhibited, contributing to high selectivity for NH3 production. In another work, dual metal atom embedded into g-C6N6 were used as electrocatalyst for N2 fixation [36]. They demonstrated that Fe–Fe atom pairs dispersed on g-C6N6 (Fe2@g-C6N6) can tune the binding strength of the intermediates, resulting in a high theoretical Faradaic efficiency of 100 % and the low limiting potential. In constrast, Niu et al. reported that single metal atom anchored on g-C6N6 can be ideal electrocatalysts for N2 reduction to NH3, with W@g-C6N6 exhibiting the lowest limiting potential of −0.29 V [37]. Given the good performance of boron atom or metal atom anchodred g-C6N6 for N2 reduction, it is expected that the construction of boron and metal atom pair on g-C6N6 can yield efficient catalysts for both electrocatalytic and photocatalytic N2 fixation. Prior studies has indicated that boron species and metal atoms could act as the effective active center for N2 fixation. Meanwhile, B dopant and metal atoms could improve conductivity and visible light response ability of substrate, inspiring the development of boron-metal dual atom catalyst (B–TM pair) for photo/electrocatalytic NRR. In addition, the synergistic effects of B and TM atom for NRR and the underlying mechanism remain largely unexplored. In this work, we aim to develop photo-assisted high-performance electrocatalysis of the N2 reduction reaction using boron paired transition metal atoms (B–Ti, B–V, B–Cr, B–Mn, B–Fe, B–Co, B–Ni, B–Zr, B–Nb, B–Mo, B–Hf, B–Ta, B–W, B–Re and B–Os) anchored on g-C6N6 through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Our result reveal that B–Os@ g-C6N6 is the most promising dual-atom catalyst for N2 reuciton to NH3, with overpotential of 0.21 V and high selectivity. Mechanistic investigations indicate that a consecutive mechanism is preferable on B–Os@ g-C6N6. In addtion, both B and Os atoms participate in N2 activation, following σ-donation and π*-back donation mechanism. Remarkably, B–Os@ g-C6N6 is demonstrated efficient electron and hole separation, high visible-light adsorption and appropriate band edge positions, which can assist the electrocatalytic N2 fixation and reduction under light irradiation. 2 Computational methods All spin-polarized calculations were carried out through VASP code [38]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed to describe electronic exchange-correlation interactions [39]. Projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to treat the ion-electron interaction. A vacuum space of 20 Å in z-direction was inserted to diminish the interaction between neighboring periodic units. DFT-D3 method was chosen to describe Van der Waals (vdW) [40]. The plane-wave cut-off energy was set to 500 eV. The Brillouin zone was sampled by 4 × 4 × 1 and 6 × 6 × 1 k-points for structure relaxation and electron structure calculations, respectively. The convergence criteria for energy and force are 10−5 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. DFT+U calculation was employed with U = 4.0 eV and J = 1.0 eV on all the TM atoms [41]. As the PBE function generally underestimates the band gap, the HSE06 function was employed to calculate bandgaps. To consider the effect of solvent on free energy change of reactions, implicit solvent was considered and embedded into VASPsol. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were conducted to evaluate the thermodynamic stability of catalysts under temperature of 300 K for 8 ps with a time step of 2 fs [42]. To evaluate the NRR activity, the Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) were calculated based on computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [43]: (1) Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E − − T Δ S in which ΔE ∆ZPE and ∆S are the differences in the total energy calculated from DFT calculations, variation of zero-point energy and entropy before and after reactions. T is the temperature at 298.15 K. The limiting potential (UL) is determined by the potential-determined step (PDS), which is indicated by the most positive ΔG in elementary steps. Therefore, The UL can be obtained by the equation below: (2) U L = − Δ G max / e Based on these, the overpotential can be obtained by the equation below: (3) η = U equilibrium − U L where the U equilibrium is the equilibrium potential of NRR (−0.16 V). The stability of B-TM@g-C6N6 was evaluated by the binding energy of B-TM (EB-TM) atom pair on g-C6N6, which can be expressed by the equation below: (4) E B − T M = E B − T M @ g − C 6 N 6 − − E T M − − E B − − E g − C 6 N 6 where EB-TM@g-C6N6, ETM, EB, and Eg-C6N6 are total energy of B-TM@g-C6N6, one TM atom and one B atoms in vacuum, and g-C6N6 monolayer, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability of B-TM@g-C6N6 In this work, a 2 × 2 × 1 g-C6N6 supercell was constructed with a lattice constant of a = b = 14.18 Å after structure relaxation, which contains 24 C atoms and 24 N atoms. The unit cell belongs to a hexagonal system with space group P 6 ¯ m2. Previous study has demonstrated that g-C6N6 nanosheet is thermodynamically stable with pore structure, making it ideal support for anchoring transition metal atoms. Meanwhile, nonmetal dopants can also be incorporated easily. As shown in Fig. S1a, the hexagonal nanopore has a diameter of 5.45 Å, providing sufficient space for the introduction of a dual- atom pair. The B atom and TM atom bond with two neighboring N atom, resulting in two five-membered rings. Two possible sites (S1 and S2) of the initial TM atom were considered (Fig. S1b). However, after structure relaxation, only Cr, Mn and Ni atoms remained stably anchored at the S2 site, while others migrated from S2 to S1 site, indicating a preference for most TM atoms to stay at the S1 site. In contrast, the B atom bond stably with two N atoms without obvious migration. Moreover, the structure of the g-C6N6 sheet maintains planar after anchoring the B–TM pair. As exhibited in Fig. S2a, a bandgap of 3.12 eV based on HSE06 function was estimated for g-C6N6, which is in good agreement with previous reports [35]. After introducing B-TM atom pair, the d orbitals of TM atoms and p orbitals of B atoms may be introduced into gap states. As a result, these introduced gap states can considerably increase the electrical conductivity and visible light response ability of g-C6N6, potentially enhancing NRR performance. To evaluate the thermodynamic ability of B-TM@g-C6N6, the binding energy (E b) of B–TM on g-C6N6 was calculated. More negative E b values indicate the stronger binding strength between B–TM atom pair and g-C6N6. As displayed in Fig. S2b, the negative E b values for all the B–TM atom pairs suggest the excellent thermodynamic stability of B–TM@g-C6N6. In addition, the distances of B-TM are close to the sum of atomic covalent radii of B and TM (Fig. S3), indicative of a certain degree of interaction between B and TM atoms. To describe the interaction of B and TM atom, the B-p and TM-d states were analyzed using partial density of states (PDOS) in Fig. S4. It can be found that B and TM shows different interaction strength. Considering the possible synergistic effect of B and TM atom on the N2 reduction process, the interaction ability between B and TM atom may influence the catalytic performance, which will be discussed later. 3.2 Screening of the DACs through N2 adsorption, the first and last protonation steps As illustrated in Fig. 1 a, the NRR is a complex process, and a ‘four step’ strategy was constructed to screen efficient catalysts, which can be divided into stability, N2 adsorption, activity and selectivity against HER. NRR process involves in six proton-coupled electron pairs (H+ + e−) transfer steps, with N2 adsorption and activation being the prerequisites for an efficient NRR. The reaction mechanisms are typically classified into associative and dissociative pathways. However, the dissociative mechanism, which involves breaking the NN triple bond, requires a high kinetic barrier, making it unlikely under milder condition. Thus, this study focuses on the associative mechanism for the considered dual-atom catalysts. It is worth noting that associative way can be further divided into four mechanisms based on the on N2 adsorption modes, including distal or alternating mechanism with end-on adsorption configurations, and consecutive or enzymatic mechanism with side-on adsorption configurations. In addition, the construction of B–TM dual atom pairs allows for three N2 adsorption configurations: side-on bridge (B–TM), side-on TM and end-on TM sites. After structure relaxation, the initial side-on bridge B-TM and side-on TM for B–Cr, B–Fe, B–Mn, and B–Ni will be transformed to end-on TM site. For B–Co, B–Cr and B-Os@g-C6N6, the initial side-on TM will be transformed to side-on bridge (B–TM) site. For the remaining B–TM@g-C6N6, the initial side-on bridge (B–TM) will be transformed to side-on TM site. Generally, the adsorption free energy of end-on adsorption configuration is more negative than that of side-on adsorption configuration. As shown in Fig. 1b, the end-on configurations exhibit more negative adsorption free energy. However, prior experiments have indicated that the electrochemical N2 reduction to NH3 can still achieve a decent rate despite an energetically unfavorable N2 adsorption, such as ΔG *N2 = 0.73 eV [44,45]. Therefore, a benchmark of 0.55 eV for N2 adsorption was established. It can be found that all ΔG *N2 on B–TM@g-C6N6 are below the 0.55 eV, implying that N2 adsorption ability is acceptable. The first hydrogenation step (*N2 to *N2H) and the sixth hydrogenation step (*NH2 to *NH3) are considered the most likely rate-determining step in the N2 reduction to NH3. The inert NN triple bond make it difficult to be activated and hydrogenated, which has to consume a lot of energy. For *NH2 to *NH3, the four sp3 hybrid orbitals of *NH3 are fully filled, while a sp3 hybrid orbital of the N atom is half-filled in *NH2, requiring energy ejection for reaction taking place. Consequently, the hydrogenation of *NH2 becomes challenging. To accelerate the process of screening promising NRR candidates, both ΔG *NNH and ΔG *NH3 < 0.55 eV was set as gauging value to evaluate the high-performance NRR catalyst. As exhibited in Fig. 1b, ΔG for most catalysts are too positive to be considered promising NRR catalyst. Nevertheless, B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6 meet these criteria. Furthermore, it can be found that free energy changes of side-on configuration are more negative than those of end-on configuration for *NNH formation on these DACs. Following the principle of minimum energy consumption, a side-on adsorption reaction pathway was determined. Therefore, it is reasonably conclusive that the consecutive or enzymatic mechanism is preferable for the reduction N2 to NH3 on the B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6 (Fig. 1c). The NRR process of the above six screened B-TM@g-C6N6 will be investigated in the following study. 3.3 Electrocatalytic NRR activity and mechanism As shown in Figs. 2 a and S5, the reaction mechanisms for the side-on adsorption configuration have been detailed, displaying the reaction pathways and configuration of all the elementary steps. After the formation of *NNH, the subsequent species *HNNH, *NNH2 and *HNNH2 determine the reaction mechanism. The ΔG *H2NN is more negative than ΔG *HNNHon the B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6. In addition, the energy consumption for the conversion of * NNH2 to *HNNH2 is higher than that of *NNH2 to *N on these DACs. These results suggest that the reduction of N2 to NH3 on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6 follows a consecutive pathway (*N2 → *NNH → NNH2 → *N → *NH → *NH2 → *NH3) rather than an enzymatic mechanism. The free energy diagrams of B–TM@g-C6N6 are calculated, as summarized in Table S1. The formation of *N2 on B–Ti, B–Zr and B–Hf@g-C6N6 are energy downhill. However, *N2 generation on B–W, B–Re and B-Os@g-C6N6 is energy uphill, with free energy barriers of 0.25, 0.27, and 0.18 eV, respectively. For the consecutive way, a proton coupled electron pair (H+ + e−) will attack the adsorbed *N2 molecule, contributing to the *NNH generation. Only B–Os@g-C6N6 shows energy downhill in this step. In particular, B–W and B–Re@g-C6N6 exhibit free energy barrier of 0.41 and 0.46 eV for *N2 to *NNH, respectively, making the conversion of *N2 to *NNH the rate-determining step of electrocatalytic NRR on these catalysts. For the second hydrogenation step, only the ΔG for *NNH2 generation on B–Zr@g-C6N6 shows energy uphill. Subsequently, the ΔG for the release of first NH3 molecule on all screened B–TM@g-C6N6 are negative, indicating that *NNH2 to *N is exothermic. In the following step, the ΔG for *NH production on B–Ti and B–Hf become positive, suggesting that extra energy injection is required. Meanwhile, *N to *NH is the rate-determining step for NRR on B–Ti@g-C6N6 due to the largest energy consumption in whole electrochemical NRR process. For the fifth hydrogenation step, the protonation of *NH to *NH2 on all catalysts is exothermic. However, in the final electrochemical reaction step, the ΔG for *NH2 to *NH3 on B–Os@g-C6N6 is negative, representing a spontaneous reaction. Conversely, this step requires overcoming free energy barriers on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, and B–Re@g-C6N6. Specifically, *NH2 to *NH3 is the rate-determining step for B–Hf@g-C6N6, demanding an energy input of 0.53 eV. Therefore, after introducing B–TM pair into g-C6N6, the rate-determining steps are different from the previous reported *N2 to *NNH or *NH2 to *NH3, which provides the insight into optimizing the adsorption strength of intermediates during NRR. For the desorption of the second NH3 molecule from the substrate, unfavorable energy barriers between 0.47 and 1.43 eV should be overcome. It is noteworthy that these results are comparable to or even smaller than those reported in previous studies, such as W@g-C6N6 (1.04 eV) [37], B@g-C3N4 (1.79 eV) [46] and B@g-C6N6 (2.23 eV) [35]. More importantly, it has been proved that NH3 detachment from the substrate is not a significant concern because NH3 can be hydrogenated into NH4 + in acidic solutions, and facilitating its desorption. Based on the obtained ΔG of rate-determining step, the limiting potential (UL) for NRR on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6 are −0.54, −0.71, −0.53, −0.41, −0.46, and −0.37 V, respectively. Of note, the ΔG for *N2 formation (non-electrochemical step) on catalysts are less than that of rate-determining step (electrochemical step), which indicates that when an external potential equal to UL is applied, all the NRR steps are exothermic. Furthermore, the overpotential for NRR on these catalysts are 0.38 V, 0.55, 0.37, 0.25, 0.30, and 0.21 V, respectively, which are significantly lower than that of Ru (0001) (0.82 V) [47], implying the lower energy cost for the electrocatalytic NRR on these catalysts. 3.4 Origin of the NRR activity on B-TM@g-C6N6 To obtain an in-depth understanding of the NRR activity on six catalysts, the initial step of N2 activation on active center was first discussed. As shown in Fig. 3 a, N2 adsorption on B–Os@g-C6N6 exhibits a side-on bridge site (B–TM), where two N atoms of N2 bond with B and Os atom, while others are side-on TM configurations. As displayed in Fig. 3a, the bond length of N2 molecule was calculated and compared. Remarkably, after formation of N2 on B–Os@g-C6N6 through side-on bridge site, the bond length of NN and BOs stretched from 1.11 to 1.23, and 2.21 to 2.67 Å, respectively. For the other five catalysts, the bond lengths of NN are also elongated but remain less than 1.20 Å. Meanwhile, Bader charge analysis suggests that two N atoms gained 0.99e- on B-Os@g-C6N6 (Fig. 3b), almost twice the amount gained on other five catalysts. This significant charge gain could be attributed to the direct participation of B atom in N2 activation. These results suggest the weakening of the NN triple bond. For the following two consecutive protonation process (*NNH and *NNH2 formation), the bond lengths of NN of adsorbed intermediates becomes longer on six catalysts with proceeding the hydrogenation, in particular, the NN bond lengths of *NNH on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–W and B–Os@g-C6N6 exceed 1.40 Å, implying that breaking NN bond and the release of first NH3 molecule are highly possible. In addition, only B–Ti and B–Zr@g-C6N6 show an increase in charge with the protonation process. It is noteworthy that the *NNH and *NNH2 on B-Os@g-C6N6 still gained more charge than other five catalysts, which is due to the fact that B and Os atom directly donate electrons to two N atoms. However, after the release of first NH3 molecule, the intermediates only bond with TM atom for most of catalysts, and B atom may act as electron transmitter. Therefore, B–Os@g-C6N6, B atom directly join in the process of breaking NN bond, however, this is not observed on other catalysts. After formation *NH, the following two hydrogenation steps for *NH to NH3 are controlled by TM atom directly. It can be deduced that a synergetic effect between B and Os atom promote the N2 activation and NH3 desorption. Furthermore, the charge density difference of *N2 on B–TM@g-C6N6 were calculated to disclose the charge transfer mechanism (Fig. S6). Interestingly, it can be found that charge accumulation and depletion occur both on B/metal and N atom for B–Os@g-C6N6, which is consistent with the well-established σ-donation and π*-backdonation mechanism for N2 activation. In detail, the empty d orbitals of Os atom and the empty sp2 orbitals of B atom accept lone-pair electrons of N2, at the same time, the occupied d orbitals of Os atom and occupied sp2 orbitals of B atom can donate electrons to the antibonding orbitals of N2 (Fig. 3c). Consequently, B–Os@g-C6N6 could effectively activate the N2 molecule. Therefore, the construction B–TM dual atom catalyst may be an efficient strategy for promoting N2 activation, contributing to the following hydrogenation steps. To distinguish the activity difference of six catalysts based on the intrinsic properties, the structure variation of substrate before and after intermediates adsorption was investigated. The projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) and integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) was employed to disclose the binding strength between B and TM atoms. As exhibited the Fig. S7, there exist remarkable antibonding states in B-Ti, B-Zr, and B-W@g-C6N6, indicating weak interaction of B to TM. The obtained ICOHP value for B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6 are −1.66, −1.81, 0.12, −1.75, 0.10 and 0.14 eV. The more negative ICOHP indicates strong binding strength of B to TM atom, resulting in charge transfer between B and TM. Therefore, the binding strength of adsorbates to active center can be optimized. Interestingly, Os atom tend to move S2 site after N2 adsorption and remain there until the release of NH3, resulting in the coordination environment of Os atom changing from B–Os–N2 to B–Os–N3. Similar changes occur on B–Re@g-C6N6 during the formation of *NNH. However, the coordination environment of Re was restored to its original state upon the formation of *NH3. In contrast, these changes are not observable on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, and B–W@g-C6N6 (Fig. S5). Therefore, it can be deduced that there exist the reversable evolution of the active center. Furthermore, it can be found that the limiting potentials of B–Re and B–Os are lower than that of B–Ti, B–Zr, and B–Hf@g-C6N6, which demonstrates that evolution of the active center can improve NRR catalytic performance. Additionally, the oxidation state of B and TM atoms were calculated based on Bader charge analysis. As depicted in Fig. 4 b, the plot of ΔG for *N2 against the total oxidation state of B and metal (δ B + δ TM) was built. Obviously, B–Os@g-C6N6 and other five B-TM@g-C6N6 catalysts fall into two distinct areas, with the ΔG for *N2 on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W and B–Re@g-C6N6 against δ B + δ TM exhibiting good scaling relationship (R 2 of 0.92). Similarly, for the *NNH, since only TM atoms bond with *NNH on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W and B–Re@g-C6N6, the area of B–Os@g-C6N6 is isolated by due to the synergetic effect of B and Os atoms (Fig. 4c and d). However, for *NH3 formation, the B atom does not directly bond with intermediate, leaving only the TM atom to bond with *NH3. As a result, scaling relationship between the ΔG *NH3 and δ B or δ TM can be constructed (Fig. 4e and f), with R2 of 0.93 and 0.92, respectively. It is thus deduced that TM as bonding atoms mainly determine the binding strength of intermediates while B atom exhibits cooperation ability trough B–TM bonding. Furthermore, Bader charge analysis on the charge variation in each elementary step was also investigated to disclose mechanistic origin. Each intermediate can be divided into three moieties as shown in Fig. S8, including adsorbed *N x H y intermediate (moiety 1), B–TM and coordinated N atoms (moiety 2), and g-C6N6 substrate (moiety 3). The charge variation based on Bader charge analysis of intermediates adsorbed on B–TM@g-C6N6 during whole NRR process was depicted in Fig. 5 . It can be observed that g-C6N6 server as an electron reservoir, while N2–B–TM–N2 acts as an electron transmitter for electron transfer between *N x H y and g-C6N6. 3.5 Photocatalytic NRR activity of B-TM@g-C6N6 Previous studies have demonstrated that light irradiation can enhance the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 on certain semiconductor materials [48]. Similarly, it is anticipated that light irradiation can also facilitate the electron transfer for activating the inert N2 molecule, thereby benefiting the N2 reduction. The high-symmetry points of system were provided in Fig. S9. The pristine g-C6N6 monolayer exhibits band gap of 3.12 eV, which is not ideal for photocatalysis due to its inability to efficiently harvest visible light. However, the introduction of B–TM atom pairs significantly alters the band structure, as illustrated in Fig. S10. The band gap of g-C6N6 monolayer is substantially reduced upon the B–TM atom pairs. The spin-up band gaps for B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6 are 0.41, 0.69, 0.50, 1.07, 0.90, 0.63 eV, respectively, while the corresponding spin-down band gaps are and 1.19, 0.69, 1.20, 0.45, 1.12, and 1.13 eV These significantly smaller band gap indicate that the incorporation of B–TM pair could effectively enhance the visible light absorption. For photocatalytic N2 reduction, the band edge of catalysts should align with the potential of N2/NH3. The potential of photogenerated electrons for NRR is defined as the energy difference between the HER potential (H+/H2) and the electron acceptor states. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the conduction band minimum (CBMs) is higher than the N2/NH3 potential (−0.16 V vs. RHE), whereas the valence band maximum (VBMs) is located below the H+/H2 potential (0.0 V vs. RHE) for B–TM@g-C6N6 catalysts. Therefore, these catalysts can assist N2 conversion under visible-light irradiation. After photoexcitation, charge transfer excitons are formed with electrons trapped on N2–B–TM–N2 moiety. Meanwhile, holes are left in valence bands. Active electrons could be injected into the antibonding orbitals of adsorbed N2, which weaken the NN triple bond. Therefore, B and TM atom can induce the impurity states in band gap, which acts as electron trapping centers that suppress photoexcited carrier recombination. In addition, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of B–TM@g-C6N6 catalysts were calculated (Fig. S11). The delocalization of HOMO and LUMO orbital in B–Ti, B–W, B–Re, and B–Os@g-C6N6 facilitates the separation of photogenerated electron and hole in different extent. Moreover, the optical absorption curves of B–TM@g-C6N6 and g-C6N6 are compared. The optical absorption edge of g-C6N6 is limited to around 300 nm. Remarkably, the decoration of B–TM atom pair on g-C6N6 extends the optical absorption into visible and infrared regions (Fig. 6b), thereby improving the photocatalytic efficiency can be improved. In brief, based on the efficient photogenerated electron and hole separation, high visible-light adsorption and appropriate band edge positions, B–Ti, B–W, B–Re, and B–Os@g-C6N6 can be predicted to have high solar conversion efficiency, thus accelerating the electrocatalytic NRR reaction by light irradiation. 3.6 Selectivity of B–TM@g-C6N6 for the NRR against HER NH3 selectivity against the HER is also a crucial criterion for evaluating the NRR performance of catalysts. Especially, H+ tends to be adsorbed on the active site in acid media, resulting in catalysts deactivation and suppression of the both reactions. Therefore, the selectivity of NRR against HER was investigated. As displayed in Fig. 7 a, the limiting potential for Heyrovsky step (H* + H+ + e− → H2) on B–Ti, B–Zr, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re and B–Os@g-C6N6 are −0.08, −0.46, −0.81, −0.94, −1.04, and −1.09 V, respectively. In contrast, the limiting potential for NH3 generation on these catalysts are −0.54, −0.71, −0.53, −0.41, −0.46, −0.37, respectively. As indicated in Fig. 7b, the horizontal and vertical axes represent the values of limiting potential of NRR and HER. It can be found that catalyst located at the bottom-right area are advantageous for NNR. Therefore, B–Hf, B–W, B–Re, and B–Os@g-C6N6 can be more selective toward NRR rather than HER. Given the excellent NRR performance on B–Os@g-C6N6, AIMD simulations are then performed at 300 K for 8 ps. As illustrated in Fig. 7c, the total energy oscillate near the initial condition and the geometric structure is remained well. It is conclusive that B–Os@g-C6N6 can be a promising catalyst for high-performance N2 fixation. 4 Conclusion In summary, a series of B-TM dual-atom pair anchored g-C6N6 toward N2 fixation and reduction to NH3 were explored through comprehensive DFT calculations. Results indicated that B-TM atom pair can be stably embedded on g-C6N6 substrate. Through a ‘Four step’ screening method, B-Hf, B-W, B-Re, and B–Os@g-C6N6 emerged as promising dual-atom catalyst for NRR, with overpotential of 0.37, 0.25, 0.30, and 0.21 V, respectively. Through the calculation of free energy change on possible elementary steps, it is determined that these catalysts follow consecutive mechanism. Especially, the origin of the highest activity of B–Os@g-C6N6 is attributed to the N2 activation through σ-donation and π*-backdonation mechanism, in which both B and Os atoms can directly involve in this process. More importantly, the adsorbates could tune coordination environment of active center, which enhanced the NRR performance. In addition, the efficient electron-hole separation and appropriate band gap indicate that B–Os@g-C6N6 has the high capability of visible-light absorption, which can assist electrocatalytic N2 conversion through visible-light irradiation. Furthermore, B–Os@g-C6N6 stands out higher selectivity toward the NRR than that of the HER. This work provides the insight into the design and construction of dual-atom catalyst combining nonmetal and metal for highly efficient N2 photoelectrochemical reduction. coredata.dc:description: The electrocatalytic reduction naturally abundant dinitrogen (N2) to ammonia (NH3) offers a promising alternative to the harsh Haber–Bosch process. However, developing catalysts for high-performance electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) remains a significant challenge. In this study, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were employed to investigate boron-transition metal atom pairs (B–TM) supported on graphitic carbon nitride (g-C6N6) as dual-atom catalysts for photo-assisted electrocatalysis of NRR. It was demonstrated that B–TM atom pair can be successfully embedded on g-C6N6. Among the considered B–TM@g-C6N6 catalysts, B–Os@g-C6N6 exhibits exceptional catalytic activity for NRR via a consecutive mechanism, with the lowest overpotential of 0.21 V, outperforming the efficiency of widely used noble catalysts. Notably, both B and Os atoms directly participate in N2 activation through σ-donation and π*-backdonation mechanism. Furthermore, the adsorption of intermediates can induce the reversable evolution of the active center, accelerating the NRR. Therefore, these novel characteristics endow B–Os dual atom catalyst with excellent NRR performance. Importantly, B–Os@g-C6N6 also shows suitable band edges and high capability of visible-light absorption, which can assist N2 conversion under visible-light irradiation. This work offers new insights and ideas for designing nonmetal-metal atom pair as dual atom catalyst for the photo-assisted electrocatalytic reduction of N2 to NH3.
